p.#text: 29. .  is used exactly as in , where the Furies refer to their  to and in Athens. 1. That . explains  is proved by the usage of Thuc. 2.  is beset with difficulties. With the MS. reading  three explanatious have been proposed: (a)  did not grow  as in population. But this does not fall in with the general line of the argument. (b)  through the presence of  advanced  () in other respects. But neither is this the argument, nor is there any proof that  can in such a connexion as this mean  (c) With regard to the rendering given above, it is denied that  can be the subject of . But, if we examine c.  as a whole, this does not appear impossible. The chapter deals with the early condition of Greece in generalthe smallness of the communities () and their weakness. To these conditions the very fertility of the soil contributed. Attica, which was barren, was an exception in both respects. It did not lose inhabitants by : it did not excite the cupidity of strangers. On the other hand, strangers settled in Attica because it offered security; and thus the population of Attica was still further increased, and it was able to colonise. These last facts lend further support to my general argument (), viz. that the weakness of the early Greeks in all respects is largely accounted for by the shifting nature of the population.  is in the writer's mind throughout.  is explained by many with reference to its other parts; but it more naturally means  A striking example of this () is the colonising energy of Attica, the consequence of freedom from migration. Of course this system of conferring civic rights belongs to a time when only the Eupatrids had any political power. They admitted new families freely. In later days, on the contrary, when Athens had attained power and the demos ruled, the Ecclesia was very jealous of the citizenship. The simple explanation of the insignificance of Mycenaenow of prime importance to the archaeologistis that the only part that could be called city was the acropolis, and that was occupied by the castle of the chief. The rest of the settlement consisted of the villages of the clans; and there is no sign that in historic times the villages ever gave way to a city. Thuc. represents the fact correctly.

p.#text: is gen. of measure, as in , almost confined to expressions of magnitude. The absence of a second art. with  is interesting: Shilleto rightly compares , where the reference is to a team, of which every member wins; just as here the two things combined are items of one fleet. As to the numbers, in Thuc.'s time the average complement of a trireme was 200. Therefore a fleet of 1200 would require 240,000 men: but the rationalistic calculation of Thuc gives about 103,000 for the Trojan War. Of course 103,000 is a far larger number than was sent out by any  state in the time of Thuc. The number of men who sailed for Sicily in 415 B C. may be roughly set down as 36,000. But  shows that Thuc. thinks of the combined forces of all Greek states, and the forces in the field during the Peloponnesian War would exceed his calculation for the Trojan War. (It seems, nevertheless, that Thuc. has not made out a very satisfactory case:  in  should have been qualified.)

p.#text: 7.   does this passage refer to the two natural stages of the expedition battle followed by siege, or two  means of taking Troy,either by pitched battle outside the gates, or by siege? Those who adopt the first, either (a) bracket the first  with Kruger as spurious, and explain the  after  as (a violent) apodotic , or, with Kruger bracket it; or else (b) make the first  mean,  capture (Troy), but, with Herbst, defeat (the Trojans). Those who adopt the second with Bauer, make  = by superiority in the field, and not being as they were superior in the field; and  = by a regular siege, instead of by persisting in a siege. But the difficulties involved in this are insuperable; forapart from the extraordinary way in which the supposed alternative methods are expressed, and joined by  instead of the sense obtained, though at first sight attractive, makes  and  pointless in so far as the  method superiority in the field + assaultis concerned; it necessitates forcing the meaning  () into , and thus making this wholly distinct from  in ; and it strains no less the meaning of . We therefore prefer the  first plan, but slightly modified; if the first  is genuine, it is probably a mere anticipation of the second. Trans.

Bloomfield's note): this cannot yield the sense in the remaining part of the summer.  must therefore be referred to , Aeolic elision. Examples of this elision of the  of  are Aesch  1145 ,  634 , and  is frequently given in MSS. for . In  the best MS. has . This means  to autumn, drawing to a close. Steup and others, following the Schol. , understand when the summer came round to mean, when the  summer came; but this does not square so well with the concluding words of the chapter, which seem to refer to the winter of the year in which the battle was fought. If drawing to a close is the meaning, then the dates would be:
Battle of Leucimme (c. ), ... Spring 435.
Return of Corinthian fleet (c. ), Autumn 435.
Corinthian preparations (c. ). Summer 435-33.

If, however, the sense is when the next summer came, the first two dates should be altered to summer 435, and spring 434. (Remember that summer in Thuc. includes spring and autumn.) In either case the calculations are based on the date of the battle of Sybota, for which see c. .

p.#text: 11. an ex. to show how Athens got a bad name as the result of her moderation. For though in suits arising out of contracts against our allies we are at a disadvantage and in our own city have instituted courts for these cases under equal laws (i.e. laws under which they and we are treated alike), we are considered litigious. .  is probably from , a contract, and not from , a treaty,  were suits arising out of international treaties; but (1) it is not clear that Athens had such  with the , and (2) it is most improbable that in all such suits an Athenian had to sue in the courts of the subject state. It is known that  were tried in the court of the defendant's state. If we assume that , commercial suits, which were tried in the state in which the contract was made, are referred to, the passage becomes clear. An Athenian litigant in the courts of the  is in an unfavourable position, whereas  in the courts at Athens are treated exactly like Athenians. Some think that  refers to the compulsory jurisdiction at Athens in certain criminal cases, when a subject ally was involved. But even when  parties were  such cases were tried at Athens, whereas Thuc. is speaking only of cases in which one party was an Athenian: so supply  in the second clause. In these latter cases the allies considered that they were badly treated. ( . On the difficulties surrounding the judicial arrangements of the Athenian League see Holm,  , Engl. Transl.)

Thuc. means clearly (it seems to me), I was going to say a year was consumed: but no, it was less than ; i.e. it was not much less. (1) In , if the text is sound, we read that the entry into Plataea took place at the very beginning of spring 431, and in the  after the battle of Potidaea (see c. ); and (2) we are further told that the first invasion of Attica was eighty days after the seizure of Plataea. p.title: Greeks
p.#text: relates that Themistocles sent a inessage to Xerxes saying that he had persuaded the Greeks not to break down the bridges over the Hellespont, and consequently the king might retreat at leisure. The story agrees with Thuc. here, except that Herod, says the message was sent from Audios, not Salamis. The true object of Them. was to cause Xerxes to retreat rapidly, since Xerxes had been once taken in by a false message from Them. (viz. that the Greeks were about to retreat from Salamis, ) and would be sure to assuine this one also was false. Them. now misrepresents the object he had had in sending the message. (Haacke and others refer  to the  message of Them., viz., that the  were about to withdraw from Salamis. By  message Them. caused the defeat of the king; by the  one he rescued the king. This explanation seems simpler; but it looks as if the parenthesis  refers only to what Them. pretends to have done to  the king.)

24. Herod. says Them. urged the Gk. fleet to break down the bridges, but he was opposed by the Peloponnesians The Athenian fleet was then willing to go alone, but this Them. successfully opposed. It looks as if Thuc. did not believe in this last part of the story. (Croiset understands which he misrepresented, others avoid the appearance of an mconsistency with Herod.)

The sense is clearly given by Arnold: Pericles is distinguishing  between two different methods of , the one by founding a city in the neighbourhood of Athens strong enough to interfere with her trade and be a check on her power, : the other by merely raising one or two forts in Attica, as strongholds for plundering parties to keep the country in constant annoyance and alarm, .
